item.title: Valve Reassessing Steam Machine Pricing Due to ‘Memory and Storage Shortages’
item.content:encoded:
Valve provides an update on the release of its Steam Machine and additional hardware slated for 2026.

Valve is once again entering the console market with its PC-console hybrid, the Steam Machine. Announced in November 2025, the new console is slated for release in the first half of 2026. Now, Valve has provided an update on its Hardware releases, some of the challenges they’re facing, and what that means for customers.

Pricing and Launch Date Remain Uncertain for Steam Machine

In a blog post on Wednesday, February 4, Valve revealed that industry-wide memory and storage shortages and rising memory prices have forced it to revisit its shipping schedule and pricing, particularly for the Steam Machine and the Steam Frame VR headset.

They still plan to ship all three products in the first half of the year, but they are currently working to finalize pricing and a specific launch date. They promise to keep customers updated as best they can.

“Our goal of shipping all three products in the first half of the year has not changed. But we have work to do to land on concrete pricing and launch dates that we can confidently announce,” they say.

The Steam Machine’s SSD and Memory Will Be Upgradable

Later in the blog, there’s an FAQ. There, Valve reveals the components of the Steam Machine and notes that both the SSD (NVMe 2230 or 2280) and memory (DDR5 SODIMMs) will be upgradable. They also claim that during test runs, most Steam titles run at 4K 60FPS with FSR on the Steam Machine.

However, they note that some titles will require more upscaling than others, and it may be preferable to play at a lower frame rate. They’re also working on HDMI VRR and investigating how to improve upscaling and optimize ray tracing performance.

While it’s not fair to say these devices are being delayed, as no concrete release date was ever given, the uncertainties players hoped would be resolved by now will continue due to the volatility of the RAM market.

item.title: Nintendo Uses Major Game Updates to Guide Players Toward Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo explains its belief that updates to Animal Crossing: New Horizons and Splatoon 3 help maintain player loyalty during the Switch-to-Switch 2 transition.

In January 2026, Nintendo launched a significant update for Animal Crossing: New Horizons. This update not only introduced additional in-game content but also quality-of-life improvements for those who pick up the Nintendo Switch 2 edition of the game. Splatoon 3 also received a major update, extending its lifecycle. Splatoon also received specific updates to support the next Nintendo Switch.

Now, Nintendo is admitting that it is trying to balance releasing new titles for its latest console with easing players into the transition from the original Nintendo Switch.

Nintendo President Discusses Transition Philosophy

During its latest investor presentation, Shuntaro Furukawa, president of Nintendo Co., Ltd., explained that major updates to existing titles are a key part of Nintendo’s philosophy because they help maintain connections with existing customers.

The belief is that it allows players to feel they are still getting value from their original Nintendo Switch while creating a pathway to adopt the next-generation console.

“As we move forward with the multi-year transition from Switch to Switch 2, we believe it is also very important to maintain contact with our customers who are currently using Nintendo consoles.

“In that sense, we thot it would be a good idea to update titles that have been big sellers on the Switch, such as ‘Animal Crossing: New Horizons’ and ‘Splatoon 3,’ at this time,” he said (via Google Translate).

Nintendo is continuing to march into its next generation. However, they are not fully finished with the original Nintendo Switch. The Nintendo Direct: Partner Showcase, scheduled for February 5, will feature games coming to both consoles. Insider Gaming will have coverage of the presentation.

item.title: Metroid Prime 4 Breaks 1 Million in Combined Sales, Nintendo Says
item.content:encoded:
For those concerned that Metroid Prime 4: Beyond failed to sell 1 million copies, there is some good news.

When Nintendo released its financial results for the end of 2025, many noted that Metroid Prime 4: Beyond was not among the games reported to have sold over a million copies. The game was released in December for both the original Nintendo Switch and the Nintendo Switch 2, leading to some being concerned that a major Nintendo release failed to meet these benchmarks.

However, Nintendo has confirmed that the game has surpassed 1 million sales across both the original and successor Nintendo Switch consoles.

Stephen Totilo on Bluesky said a Nintendo representative told him the combined sales surpassed the metric.

Metroid Prime 4 Was the Final Game for Nintendo Dev

In the wake of the release of Metroid Prime 4, Kensuke Tanabe, a legendary producer at Nintendo known for his work on the franchise, confirmed that this would be the final game that he would work on at Nintendo.

Metroid Prime 4 was announced in 2017 and took nearly a decade to release, after the project switched development Studios from Bandai Namco to Retro Studios. Ultimately, the game received favorable reviews, but many admitted it failed to live up to the legacy of earlier games in the franchise.

Nintendo continues to march into the future with a Nintendo Direct: Partner Showcase on February 5, announcing more games coming to the Nintendo Switch 2 and some that will release on the original Nintendo Switch. Insider Gaming will have full coverage of the presentation on February 5.

item.title: Black Myth: Wukong Will Release on Nintendo Switch 2, It’s Claimed
item.content:encoded:
Ahead of the Nintendo Direct: Partner Showcase on February 5, a reliable leaker has shared news about a potential massive 2024 title coming to the Nintendo Switch 2.

Nate the Hate claimed on his podcast discussing the forthcoming Direct that he has heard Black Myth: Wukong will be coming to the Nintendo Switch 2. He could not confirm whether the game would be showcased in the February Nintendo Direct, but he remains confident it will arrive on Nintendo’s latest home console.

The game sold tens of millions of copies early in its lifecycle and was named best action game at the 2024 Game Awards.

The Future of the Black Myth Franchise

No downloadable content has ever dropped for the popular Journey to the West-inspired title. However, a reveal trailer for Black Myth: Zhong Kui was shown at Gamescom Opening Night Live 2025.

That game is not expected to be a direct sequel to Wukong, but Game Science has indicated that more could follow from that specific story in the future. Still, it remains unclear if Black Myth: Wukong’s story will continue through a direct sequel in a new title or via DLC for the original game. Learn more about that here.

Insider Gaming will have full coverage of the Nintendo Direct on February 5.

item.title: Overwatch Receiving Nintendo Switch 2 Edition in Spring 2026
item.content:encoded:
Overwatch may be dropping the “2” from its name, but it’s trading it in for the Nintendo Switch 2.

Details remain scarce, but the development team announced that Overwatch is heading to the Nintendo Switch 2 in Spring 2026. The announcement was made during the Overwatch Spotlight on Thursday, February 4, 2026. The game was released on the original Nintendo Switch. As such, it is playable on the successor console. However, a dedicated Switch 2 release would mean some likely upgrades and optimization for the new hardware.

As of yet, there is no specific release date attached to the release of Overwatch: Nintendo Switch 2 Edition.

More News From the Overwatch Spotlight

The big announcement from the showcase was the reveal of a year-long story arc known as “The Reign of Talon.” Reign of Talon will be a 6-season storyline, introducing five new heroes, new in-game events, and more. A new arc will then commence in early 2027.

Also, it was announced that Overwatch, which had renamed itself “Overwatch 2” in 2022, will revert to its original name. Players can learn more about that mindset behind that decision here.

For more Nintendo Switch 2 news on Insider Gaming, learn more about the Apex Legends update coming to Nintendo platforms and why the original Nintendo Switch only has a few more months to pick up the latest Nintendo console.

item.title: Marathon Ranked Mode Details Leak, Including Tiers and Rewards
item.content:encoded:
Marathon will include a ranked mode, and a new report provides the first look into its details.

Bungie has not officially confirmed many details about the upcoming extraction shooter, Marathon. However, new details have been shared with MP1st courtesy of leaker X0X_Leak.

The ranked mode in the upcoming game will have 6 tiers, with discussion of a 7th “Master” tier. The 6 tiers mentioned in the report are Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, Diamond, and Pinnacle. Each tier has three individual sub-rankings as players level up. Ranked rewards will include cosmetics and other items, some of which players will be able to equip directly, and others will be gifted to them after a season is over.

Scoring Details for Marathon Ranked Mode

The report goes on to mention scoring details, noting that players must have a Holotag equipped to score in a match. There is no Holotag equipped; there will be no contribution to the score. If players successfully exfil from a ranked match before reaching the target score, no rank progress is gained or lost. Failing to exfil results in a point loss equal to the full Score target.

Holotags have rarities equivalent to the ranks mentioned above. Each tag has unique effects that boost score targets when looted from other Runners during a match, also enabling potential scores higher than the initial target.

For example, a Silver Holotag grants players 5,000 credits to their score target on Infil, and any additional looted silver tags expand players’ credit capacities by 1,000.

item.title: AI is ‘Here and It’s Not Going Anywhere’ Admits Kingdom Come Director
item.content:encoded:
Daniel Vávra, the writer and director of Kingdom Come: Deliverance and Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, has posted a predictive and somewhat damning statement about artificial intelligence on social media. He was responding to a video showcasing the insane advancements of photorealistic, gen-AI video creation tools, which are fast becoming terrifying.

Vávra, a games industry veteran of more than 20 years, stressed that movies and gaming ‘will never be the same’, and suggested we need to make the most of it because of the benefits it offers.

‘Everybody Hates AI (Well Actually, Not Everybody)’

In a recent statement that some might dub inflammatory, Daniel Vávra, the creative director of 2025’s Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, bigged up generative AI. He wrote:

Everybody hates AI (well actually not everybody). But I told you its unavoidable future.

Hate me as you wish. Its the truth. This is fan made trailer. Made in two days. By one person. Movie (and gaming) industry will never be the same. You can see it as an game over or as an opportunity for everyone to make great stuff without the big money from corporations.

But it doesnt matter what you think. Its here and its not going anywhere.

Vávra suggests that pushing back against AI is a fruitless effort, as it’s inevitable that the technology will continue to evolve. Instead, Vávra indicates that a symbiosis of sorts is the best way forward, using the progressive technology as a way to make things better and faster without gargantuan investments from ‘corporations’.

It’s no big secret that more developers are falling into the use of AI these days. It allows them to iterate faster, test more effectively, and create games, especially larger ones, at a much more efficient pace. The sketchy area comes when generative AI is used to replace artists, musicians, and actors, and it has caused an intense amount of flak across the industry in recent years.

In a throwback interview with Insider Gaming, Doug Cockle (Geralt of Rivia, The Witcher) named AI voice replication ‘theft’. It was a sentiment that has been echoed countless times since.

Vávra gave his thoughts back to those opposing his energy towards AI, offering up an analogy of sorts:

My “art” is just a materialization of my thoughts, the result of my brain guiding my hands. Its similar as if you were saying that driving cars is unnatural cheating to reach something faster and only peple who really arrive in destination are those who walk…

It’s rough, but it makes quite a lot of sense, and it’s one of the biggest debates around the use of AI. Are you inherently evil or immoral for using AI to make your life easier, and is it better to struggle, take longer to do things, and spend more money just to declare you’re not using AI for something?

Do you think Daniel Vávra’s comments are acceptable? Let us know what you’re thinking on the Insider Gaming Discord server.
